senses.sense: (colloquial) Regretful, sorry; expressing a reluctance to face an unpleasant situation.
examples: I am afraid I cannot help you in this matter.

senses.sense: (used with for) Worried about, feeling concern for, fearing for (someone or something).
The state or quality of being afraid.
Alternative spelling of ifrit
plural of afreet
Anew; again; once more
examples: We ditched the original design, and decided to start afresh.

senses.sense: Alternative form of affright
Alternative spelling of ifrit
Alternative form of ifrit
plural of afrit
hairstyle characterized by tightly curled locks and a rounded shape.
A person of African ancestry
in front; face to face
in front of
(countable) Any of the African leguminous trees of the genus Pericopsis (formerly Afrormosia), especially Pericopsis elata
(uncountable) Timber of these trees.
plural of afro
frowning
examples: faces all afrown

senses.sense: (nautical) The stern portion of a vessel.
(nautical) At, near, or towards the stern of a vessel (with the frame of reference within the vessel).
located at the back of a boat, ship, or airplane
(dated slang) Alternative form of afternoon: the time of day from noon until early evening.
A Persian ewer.
Behind; later in time; following.
examples: I left the room, and the dog bounded after.
They lived happily ever after.
I might come next month, or the month after.

senses.sense: Subsequently to; following in time; later than.
examples: We had a few beers after the game.
The time is quarter after eight.
The Cold War began shortly after WWII.
After you with the salt/paper.
I told her to shut the door after her.

senses.sense: (in reduplicative expressions) Repeatedly, seemingly is a sequence without end.
examples: day after day, time after time, mile after mile, beer after beer, smile after smile

senses.sense: Behind.
examples: He will leave a trail of destruction after him.

senses.sense: In pursuit of, seeking.
examples: He's after a job; run after him; inquire after her health.

senses.sense: In allusion to, in imitation of; following or referencing.
examples: We named him after his grandfather; a painting after Leonardo da Vinci.

senses.sense: Next in importance or rank.
examples: The princess is next in line to the throne after the prince.

senses.sense: As a result of.
examples: After your bad behaviour, you will be punished.

senses.sense: In spite of.
examples: After all that has happened, he is still my friend.
I can't believe that, after all our advice against gambling, you walked into that casino!

senses.sense: (Irish, usually preceded by a form of be, followed by an -ing form of a verb) Used to indicate recent completion of an activity
examples: I was after finishing my dinner when there was a knock on the door.

senses.sense: (dated) According to an author or text.
Denoting the aim or object; concerning; in relation to.
examples: to look after workmen; to enquire after a friend; to thirst after righteousness

senses.sense: (obsolete) According to the direction and influence of; in proportion to; befitting.
Signifies that the action of the clause it starts takes place before the action of the other clause.
examples: I went home after we had decided to call it a day.

senses.sense: (dated) Later; second (of two); next, following, subsequent
(nautical, where the frame of reference is within the ship) At or towards the stern of a ship.
examples: The after gun is mounted aft.
The after gun is abaft the forward gun.

senses.sense: An age occurring afterwards; a later era.
(hydrology) a stream, conduit, pond or reservoir, of a hydroelectric power plant at the outlet of the turbines.
(music) A secondary, weaker half of a musical beat.
The placenta and other material expelled via the birth canal following childbirth or parturition in mammals.
plural of afterbirth
plural of afterbody
The afterpart of a vehicle.
(nautical) The part of a vessel abaft midships.
(astronomy) A companion body that trails a satellite or spacecraft.
(astronautics) A section or piece of a launch vehicle, rocket, or spacecraft that enters the atmosphere unprotected behind the nose cone or other body that is protected for entry.
(anatomy) A posterior subdivision of the hindbrain; the myelencephalon
(aviation) A device in a jet engine which injects fuel into the exhaust system to increase the thrust.
plural of afterburner
(aviation) The injection of extra fuel into a jet engine downstream of the turbines in order to achieve extra thrust.
(medicine) The care given to a patient during recovery from an operation or after hospitalization.
(business, frequently attributive) Services and support offered to a customer for the goods or service they have purchased.
Emotional support offered by the programme makers to a person who has appeared on a stressful talk show, etc.
(BDSM) Tender affection and care given to a partner after a BDSM activity, usually to serve as a transition between the activity and whatever follows it.
Childcare services tending to children after the school day.
(dated) The career that follows a particular experience or stage in a person's life; later career.
(art) A reproduction work made by reusing a cast.
A throw of dice after the game is ended.
A medical condition of clouding of the posterior lens capsule implanted in the eye in cataract surgery.
After attending a church.
(archaic) An additional adverse event that occurs unexpectedly after an earlier one was thought to be over and done with.
(archaic) An unfavourable turn of events following a favourable situation; an eventuality for which one ought to be prepared.
The consequence (often, but not always, adverse) of an action or event.
A phenomenon occurring after a similar earlier one; a later manifestation of something.
A sound that follows another, especially a loud noise, such as thunder.
A symptom of an illness, especially one that appears after the initial onset; an illness or symptom caused by exposure to a substance, an injury, etc.
(uncountable, medical, obsolete) Urethral discharge as a symptom of gonorrhea.
(obsolete) A change or attempted change to an agreement after it has been entered into; an additional charge (especially one over and above the previously agreed-upon price).
(humorous) A child born after the one that was intended to be the last.
(slang, obsolete) A sweet food, drink, or tobacco product consumed at the end of a meal.
(South Africa, historical) A canvas curtain or tailboard at the rear of a covered wagon.
(archaic, Scotland) A subsequent result; consequence.
One coming after; a successor; (in the plural) posterity.
A following state, sequel, consequence, or result; an aftercome.
Succeeding, following.
(obstetrics) Specifically, of a baby's head: following the rest of the body out of the womb, rather than (as is usual) preceding it.
An intercooler located at the end of the supercharging chain.
(accounting) A subsequent expense related to but occurring after the source of an expenditure.
(by extension) A subsequent burden or loss resulting from an endeavor.
The course (sequence of events or actions) that follows something; subsequent course.
(archaic, regional) The final course of a meal.
(obsolete) A subsequent course of study.
A second crop in the same year.
(mining) Suffocating gases present in a coal mine after an explosion caused by firedamp, consisting of carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, nitrogen, and sometimes hydrogen sulfide.
postdated
(archaic) Days that follow; a later time or period; (figuratively) people in the future.
Disadvantage.
(nautical) The part of a ship's deck from amidships toward the stern
plural of afterdeck
Any discharge that occurs after the cause or stimulus has ceased
Any delayed effect; an effect which is not immediately manifested.
plural of aftereffect
plural of afterfruit
(archaic) A second game played to reverse the outcome of the first; the means employed after the first turn of affairs.
(video games) Bonus features, dialogue, etc. accessed when a previously-beaten video game is revisited.
The glow seen in the sky after sunset.
The light emitted by an incandescent object while cooling.
The light emitted by a phosphor after excitation.
The mildly euphoric feeling experienced after a pleasurable experience, especially after an orgasm or drug-induced high.
An afterparty.
examples: There's an afterglow with singing after the evening worship.

senses.sense: plural of afterglow
The grass that grows after the first crop has been mown.
A second growth, seen in plants like crops or timber after harvesting.
(figuratively) Any abstraction of the above.
(historical, nautical) The seaman or seamen stationed on the poop or after part of a ship, to attend the after-sails.
(sailing) The members of a yacht's crew who attend to the aft sails
A drudge; somebody tasked with menial work.
(Scotland, legal, archaic) Paid afterwards, rather than in advance.
examples: an afterhand rent

senses.sense: (archaic) Afterwards; subsequently.
Residual useful heat obtained from a nuclear reactor during aftercooling
An image which persists or remains in negative after the original stimulation has ended.
plural of afterimage
Alternative spelling of after-impression
The last milk that is obtained when milking a cow. Often considered the poorest quality of milk.
examples: All that was left in the cow were the afterings.

senses.sense: (by extension) The last of any substance that is of a poorer quality than the earlier substance, e.g. the dregs of coffee.
Knowledge acquired later, or after the event.
A conscious existence after death.
examples: Many religious people believe in an afterlife.

senses.sense: The place believed to be inhabited by people who have died.
(countable, uncountable) The part of a person's life that follows a particular stage or event; later life.
The effects of a person's actions, or their reputation, after death.
The events or situations that result from a particular event; the later reception, consumption or reworking of a cultural production such as a film, book, etc.
examples: The 1970s TV show M*A*S*H had a long afterlife in syndication.

senses.sense: Light that follows something, especially the dim light in the sky after the sun has fully set.
plural of afterlife
(business) The market for further goods and services, such as replacement parts and accessories, subsequent to the sale of a product such as an automobile or computer.
(business) The industry that serves that market.
(finance) Trading activity in a security immediately following its initial offering to the public.
(business) To sell goods or services in the aftermarket.
(nautical) A mast located towards the stern of a ship.
(obsolete, agriculture) A second mowing; the grass which grows after the first crop of hay in the same season.
That which happens after, that which follows, usually of strongly negative connotation in most contexts, implying a preceding catastrophe.
examples: In contrast to most projections of the aftermath of nuclear war, in this there is no rioting or looting.

senses.sense: plural of aftermath
(nautical) Nearest the stern of a vessel.
(obsolete) Most recent.
(obsolete) At the very back.
The part of the day from noon or lunchtime until sunset, evening, or suppertime or 6pm.
(figuratively) The later part of anything, often with implications of decline.
(informal) A party or social event held in the afternoon.
(archaic in the singular) In the afternoon.
Ellipsis of good afternoon
plural of afternoon
Every afternoon.
examples: We are closed afternoons.

senses.sense: A note appended after the main body of text.
(pathology, often in the plural) pain of uterine contractions experienced after childbirth (especially after passage of the placenta)
plural of afterpain
A rear part
(nautical) The compartment nearest the stern in the hold of a ship
(now chiefly historical) An additional work following the main work; especially, a minor entertainment performed after a play.
(nautical) The heel of a rudder.
In human sexual behavior, the erotic acts done after finishing sex.

A small, transitory electrical potential that follows, and is dependent upon the main potential produced when a nerve is stimulated; seen as a small positive or negative spike on an oscillograph output.
(British, informal, uncountable) Dessert.
examples: ''What are we having for afters, Mum? I really want ice cream.''

senses.sense: (informal) The festivities held after a wedding meal.
examples: To keep costs down at our wedding, we only had family at the banquet, but invited all our friends to the afters.

senses.sense: (British, Irish, informal, sport) Fighting or arguing off the ball or when play has stopped.
(UK) An After-hours drinking session in a public house.
Taking place immediately after school classes.
Of or pertaining to a program intended to care for and educate children in the time immediately after school classes.
A delayed sensation; one arising significantly later than the stimulus that caused it.
(ornithology) An accessory plume arising from the posterior of the contour feathers of many birds.
a lotion, gel, or liquid used after finishing shaving
plural of aftershave
An earthquake that follows in the same vicinity as another, usually larger, earthquake (the "mainshock").
(figuratively) By extension, any result or consequence following a major event.
Emotional and physical distress following a traumatic event.
plural of aftershock
A sound that persists or remains audible after its source has ceased to produce it; the perception of such a sound.
(acoustics) The second, slower phase of decay in the sound made by a piano string when it is struck.
(phonetics, obsolete) A weaker sound that immediately follows a more salient one, such as the second, less prominent vowel sound in a falling diphthong.
A swarm of bees that leaves the hive after the primary swarm.
A taste of something that persists when it is no longer present.
The persistence of the taste of something no longer present.
examples: Many people think certain artificial sweeteners have an unpleasant aftertaste.

senses.sense: (of wine) finish.
plural of aftertaste
Alternative spelling of after-tax.
One who acts first and thinks afterwards.
A reflection after an act; a later or subsequent thought, action, or expedient.
examples: She packed her sandals only as an afterthought, but she was glad she did.

senses.sense: Something additional to the original plan or concept.
examples: This whole remodeling was an afterthought; we were only going to paint and call it good.

senses.sense: (very rare except in the past tense, possibly nonstandard) To expound as an afterthought.
simple past tense and past participle of afterthink
simple past tense and past participle of afterthought
plural of afterthought
A later time; the future.

(music) The process in which a harmony singer or background singer repeats a line or a series of words in a song separately after the lead singer rather than singing it in unison with the lead singer; prominent in country music and Southern gospel.
plural of aftertime
(music, uncountable) Pressure sensitivity on an electronic synthesizer, allowing the musician to change the tone or sound of a note after it is struck.
(rare) A touch (feature or characteristic) added finally or as an afterthought.
(video games) A feature in football/soccer games allowing the player to swerve the ball immediately after kicking it.
Following a war.
(US) Alternative form of afterwards
(temporal location) At a later or succeeding time.
(US, dialect) Afterwards.
Wise after the fact.
Wisdom which comes after the event.
The lack of forethought.
A good comeback, retort one thinks of only after the end of discussion or after leaving a social gathering.
(dated) Characterized by afterwit; slow-witted.
an epilogue.
(of a letter) a postscript.
(to a book) an appendix.
A supposed world that is entered after death; the realm of the afterlife.
subsequent years
Furthest aft, most sternward, as far back as possible.
(veterinary medicine) foot-and-mouth disease
(nautical) by, near, at, or towards, the stern
(nautical) Toward the stern.
Alternative form of aftward
Lack of function; failure to work properly.
Not functional.
